## [§](https://docs.rs/k256/latest/k256/#rustcrypto-secp256k1-k-256-elliptic-curve)[RustCrypto](https://github.com/RustCrypto/): secp256k1 (K-256) elliptic curve
[![crate](https://buildstats.info/crate/k256)](https://crates.io/crates/k256) [![Docs](https://docs.rs/k256/badge.svg)](https://docs.rs/k256/) [![Build Status](https://github.com/RustCrypto/elliptic-curves/workflows/k256/badge.svg?branch=master&event=push)](https://github.com/RustCrypto/elliptic-curves/actions?query=workflow%3Ak256) ![Apache2/MIT licensed](https://img.shields.io/badge/license-Apache2.0/MIT-blue.svg) ![Rust Version](https://img.shields.io/badge/rustc-1.65+-blue.svg) [![Project Chat](https://img.shields.io/badge/zulip-join_chat-blue.svg)](https://rustcrypto.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/260040-elliptic-curves)
[secp256k1](https://en.bitcoin.it/wiki/Secp256k1) (a.k.a. K-256) elliptic curve library written in pure Rust with support for [ECDSA](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elliptic_Curve_Digital_Signature_Algorithm) signing/verification/public-key recovery, Taproot [Schnorr signatures](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Schnorr_signature) as defined in BIP340, Elliptic Curve Diffie-Hellman (ECDH), and general-purpose secp256k1 elliptic curve group operations which can be used to implement arbitrary group-based protocols.
Uses traits and base types from the [`elliptic-curve`](https://github.com/RustCrypto/traits/tree/master/elliptic-curve) crate.
Optionally includes a secp256k1 [`arithmetic`](https://docs.rs/k256/latest/k256/arithmetic/index.html) feature providing scalar and point types (projective/affine) with support for constant-time scalar multiplication. Additionally, implements traits from the [`group`](https://github.com/zkcrypto/group) crate which can be used to generically construct group-based protocols.
[Documentation](https://docs.rs/k256/)
### [§](https://docs.rs/k256/latest/k256/#security-notes)Security Notes
This crate has been [audited by NCC Group](https://research.nccgroup.com/2023/08/30/public-report-entropy-rust-cryptography-review/), which found a high severity issue in the ECDSA/secp256k1 implementation and another high severity issue in the Schnorr/secp256k1 signature implementation, both of which have since been corrected. We would like to thank [Entropy](https://entropy.xyz/) for funding the audit.
This crate has been designed with the goal of ensuring that secret-dependent secp256k1 operations are performed in constant time (using the `subtle` crate and constant-time formulas). However, it is not suitable for use on processors with a variable-time multiplication operation (e.g. short circuit on multiply-by-zero / multiply-by-one, such as certain 32-bit PowerPC CPUs and some non-ARM microcontrollers).
USE AT YOUR OWN RISK!
### [§](https://docs.rs/k256/latest/k256/#supported-algorithms)Supported Algorithms
  * [Elliptic Curve Diffie-Hellman (ECDH)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elliptic-curve_Diffie-Hellman): gated under the `ecdh` feature. Note that this is technically ephemeral secp256k1 Diffie-Hellman (a.k.a. ECDHE)
  * [Elliptic Curve Digital Signature Algorithm (ECDSA)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elliptic_Curve_Digital_Signature_Algorithm): gated under the `ecdsa` feature. Support for ECDSA/secp256k1 signing and verification, applying [low-S normalization (BIP 0062)](https://github.com/bitcoin/bips/blob/master/bip-0062.mediawiki) as used in consensus-critical applications, and additionally supports secp256k1 public-key recovery from ECDSA signatures (as used by e.g. Ethereum)
  * Taproot [Schnorr signatures](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Schnorr_signature) (as defined in [BIP0340](https://github.com/bitcoin/bips/blob/master/bip-0340.mediawiki)): next-generation signature algorithm based on group operations enabling elegant higher-level constructions like multisignatures.


### [§](https://docs.rs/k256/latest/k256/#about-secp256k1-k-256)About secp256k1 (K-256)
[secp256k1](https://en.bitcoin.it/wiki/Secp256k1) is a Koblitz curve commonly used in cryptocurrency applications. The “K-256” name follows NIST notation where P = prime fields, B = binary fields, and K = Koblitz curves.
The curve is specified as `secp256k1` by Certicom’s SECG in “SEC 2: Recommended Elliptic Curve Domain Parameters”:
<https://www.secg.org/sec2-v2.pdf>
secp256k1 is primarily notable for usage in Bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies, particularly in conjunction with the [Elliptic Curve Digital Signature Algorithm (ECDSA)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elliptic_Curve_Digital_Signature_Algorithm). Owing to its wide deployment in these applications, secp256k1 is one of the most popular and commonly used elliptic curves.
### [§](https://docs.rs/k256/latest/k256/#minimum-supported-rust-version)Minimum Supported Rust Version
Rust **1.65** or higher.
Minimum supported Rust version can be changed in the future, but it will be done with a minor version bump.
### [§](https://docs.rs/k256/latest/k256/#semver-policy)SemVer Policy
  * All on-by-default features of this library are covered by SemVer
  * MSRV is considered exempt from SemVer as noted above


### [§](https://docs.rs/k256/latest/k256/#license)License
All crates licensed under either of
  * [Apache License, Version 2.0](http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0)
  * [MIT license](http://opensource.org/licenses/MIT)


at your option.
#### [§](https://docs.rs/k256/latest/k256/#contribution)Contribution
Unless you explicitly state otherwise, any contribution intentionally submitted for inclusion in the work by you, as defined in the Apache-2.0 license, shall be dual licensed as above, without any additional terms or conditions.
### [§](https://docs.rs/k256/latest/k256/#serde-support)`serde` support
When the `serde` feature of this crate is enabled, `Serialize` and `Deserialize` are impl’d for the following types:
  * [`AffinePoint`](https://docs.rs/k256/latest/k256/struct.AffinePoint.html "struct k256::AffinePoint")
  * [`Scalar`](https://docs.rs/k256/latest/k256/struct.Scalar.html "struct k256::Scalar")
  * [`ecdsa::VerifyingKey`](https://docs.rs/k256/latest/k256/ecdsa/type.VerifyingKey.html "type k256::ecdsa::VerifyingKey")


Please see type-specific documentation for more information.
## Re-exports[§](https://docs.rs/k256/latest/k256/#reexports)

`pub use elliptic_curve[](https://docs.rs/elliptic-curve/0.13.8/x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu/elliptic_curve/index.html "mod elliptic_curve");`


`pub use elliptic_curve::pkcs8[](https://docs.rs/pkcs8/0.10.2/x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu/pkcs8/index.html "mod pkcs8");``pkcs8`


`pub use sha2[](https://docs.rs/sha2/0.10.9/x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu/sha2/index.html "mod sha2");``sha2`

## Modules[§](https://docs.rs/k256/latest/k256/#modules)

[ecdh](https://docs.rs/k256/latest/k256/ecdh/index.html "mod k256::ecdh")`ecdh`
    Elliptic Curve Diffie-Hellman (Ephemeral) Support.

[ecdsa](https://docs.rs/k256/latest/k256/ecdsa/index.html "mod k256::ecdsa")`ecdsa-core`
    Elliptic Curve Digital Signature Algorithm (ECDSA).

[schnorr](https://docs.rs/k256/latest/k256/schnorr/index.html "mod k256::schnorr")`schnorr`
    Taproot Schnorr signatures as defined in [BIP340](https://github.com/bitcoin/bips/blob/master/bip-0340.mediawiki).
## Structs[§](https://docs.rs/k256/latest/k256/#structs)

[AffinePoint](https://docs.rs/k256/latest/k256/struct.AffinePoint.html "struct k256::AffinePoint")`arithmetic`
    secp256k1 curve point expressed in affine coordinates.

[ProjectivePoint](https://docs.rs/k256/latest/k256/struct.ProjectivePoint.html "struct k256::ProjectivePoint")`arithmetic`
    A point on the secp256k1 curve in projective coordinates.

[Scalar](https://docs.rs/k256/latest/k256/struct.Scalar.html "struct k256::Scalar")`arithmetic`
    Scalars are elements in the finite field modulo n.

[Secp256k1](https://docs.rs/k256/latest/k256/struct.Secp256k1.html "struct k256::Secp256k1")
    secp256k1 (K-256) elliptic curve.
## Type Aliases[§](https://docs.rs/k256/latest/k256/#types)

[CompressedPoint](https://docs.rs/k256/latest/k256/type.CompressedPoint.html "type k256::CompressedPoint")
    Compressed SEC1-encoded secp256k1 (K-256) curve point.

[EncodedPoint](https://docs.rs/k256/latest/k256/type.EncodedPoint.html "type k256::EncodedPoint")
    SEC1-encoded secp256k1 (K-256) curve point.

[FieldBytes](https://docs.rs/k256/latest/k256/type.FieldBytes.html "type k256::FieldBytes")
    secp256k1 (K-256) field element serialized as bytes.

[NonZeroScalar](https://docs.rs/k256/latest/k256/type.NonZeroScalar.html "type k256::NonZeroScalar")`arithmetic`
    Non-zero secp256k1 (K-256) scalar field element.

[PublicKey](https://docs.rs/k256/latest/k256/type.PublicKey.html "type k256::PublicKey")`arithmetic`
    secp256k1 (K-256) public key.

[SecretKey](https://docs.rs/k256/latest/k256/type.SecretKey.html "type k256::SecretKey")
    secp256k1 (K-256) secret key.

[U256](https://docs.rs/k256/latest/k256/type.U256.html "type k256::U256")
    256-bit unsigned big integer.

[WideBytes](https://docs.rs/k256/latest/k256/type.WideBytes.html "type k256::WideBytes")
    Bytes used by a wide reduction: twice the width of [`FieldBytes`](https://docs.rs/k256/latest/k256/type.FieldBytes.html "type k256::FieldBytes").

readme_summary: The `k256` crate is a pure Rust implementation of the secp256k1 (K-256) elliptic curve, widely used in cryptocurrency applications like Bitcoin and Ethereum. It supports key cryptographic operations, including ECDSA signing/verification, Schnorr signatures (BIP340), and Elliptic Curve Diffie-Hellman (ECDH), with optional constant-time arithmetic for secure scalar and point operations. The crate is audited for security, integrates with the `elliptic-curve` and `group` traits, and offers `serde` support for key types.
factual_counterfactual:
### Pair 1: Supported Algorithms  
✅ **Factual**: The `k256` crate supports Elliptic Curve Digital Signature Algorithm (ECDSA) signing and verification, including low-S normalization as defined in BIP 0062, which is critical for consensus in Bitcoin applications.  
❌ **Counterfactual**: The `k256` crate supports RSA-based digital signatures alongside ECDSA for broader cryptographic use cases.  

---

### Pair 2: Constant-Time Operations  
✅ **Factual**: The `k256` crate is designed to ensure secret-dependent secp256k1 operations are performed in constant time, leveraging the `subtle` crate and constant-time formulas to mitigate timing attacks.  
❌ **Counterfactual**: The `k256` crate guarantees constant-time operations on all processors, including those with variable-time multiplication operations like certain 32-bit PowerPC CPUs.  

---

### Pair 3: Feature Gating  
✅ **Factual**: The `k256` crate provides optional feature flags such as `ecdh` for Elliptic Curve Diffie-Hellman and `ecdsa` for ECDSA functionality, enabling users to include only the capabilities they need.  
❌ **Counterfactual**: The `k256` crate requires all features to be enabled by default, including `ecdh`, `ecdsa`, and `arithmetic`, regardless of the user's specific requirements.
